channel.title: NPR Programs: All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Scientists are genetically modifying wildlife. Should they be released in the wild?
item.description: Humans can genetically modify plants and animals to be more resilient to climate change and disease. But the scientific community is divided about whether the tool should be put to use in nature.
item.content:encoded: Humans can genetically modify plants and animals to be more resilient to climate change and disease. But the scientific community is divided about whether the tool should be put to use in nature.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Rott

item.title: Locals step up to serve visitors to Acadia National Park during government shutdown
item.description: Acadia National Park and Bar Harbor fared through a peak weekend for tourism with the park open, but many facilities inside it unstaffed.
item.content:encoded: Acadia National Park and Bar Harbor fared through a peak weekend for tourism with the park open, but many facilities inside it unstaffed.
item.dc:creator: Kaitlyn Budion

item.title: The elite, yet friendly, world of producing giant pumpkins
item.description: Fall means giant pumpkin contests in some places. At the Topsfield Fair in Massachusetts, we meet the next generation of competitors and their mentors.
item.content:encoded: Fall means giant pumpkin contests in some places. At the Topsfield Fair in Massachusetts, we meet the next generation of competitors and their mentors.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Beland

item.title: Madagascar's military takes control after president flees
item.description: The military have taken control of Madagascars government, as the President flees the country.
item.content:encoded: The military have taken control of Madagascars government, as the President flees the country.
item.dc:creator: Emmanuel Akinwotu

item.title: D'Angelo, R&B's reluctant icon, dies at 51
item.description: Known as a perfectionist, the singer emerged in the 1990s during the neo-soul movement with his classic debut, Brown Sugar. He made just two more albums, Voodoo and Black Messiah. Both were treasured.
item.content:encoded: Known as a perfectionist, the singer emerged in the 1990s during the neo-soul movement with his classic debut, Brown Sugar. He made just two more albums, Voodoo and Black Messiah. Both were treasured.
item.dc:creator: Rodney Carmichael

item.title: Airports are refusing to play a Kristi Noem video blaming Democrats for the shutdown
item.description: Multiple airports across the U.S. are refusing to play a Department of Homeland Security video blaming Democrats for the government shutdown, with some saying it violates the Hatch Act.
item.content:encoded: Multiple airports across the U.S. are refusing to play a Department of Homeland Security video blaming Democrats for the government shutdown, with some saying it violates the Hatch Act.
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Diaz

item.title: In new memoir, John T. Edge explores Southern identity and a troubled family history
item.description: Writer John T. Edge has spent much of his career telling stories about a changing American South filtered through the lens of food and culture. Now he's talking about his troubled family's history.
item.content:encoded:
Writer John T. Edge has spent much of his career telling stories about a changing American South filtered through the lens of food and culture. Now he's talking about his troubled family's history.

(Image credit: Debbie Elliott)
item.dc:creator: Debbie Elliott

item.title: Here to Help: Volunteers bring books to West Virginia kids who are far from libraries
item.description: A group of volunteers in West Virginia makes sure preschoolers in areas with no libraries or bookstores get books to read.
item.content:encoded: A group of volunteers in West Virginia makes sure preschoolers in areas with no libraries or bookstores get books to read.
item.dc:creator: Chris Schulz

item.title: Israeli doctor details the rehabilitation process for returning hostages
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with Dr. Hagai Levine, head of the medical team for the Hostages and Missing Families Forum, about the road to recovery for hostages just released from captivity.
item.content:encoded: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with Dr. Hagai Levine, head of the medical team for the Hostages and Missing Families Forum, about the road to recovery for hostages just released from captivity.
item.dc:creator: Mary Louise Kelly

item.title: Grains, sheep and soldiers: How one scientist is studying the physics of crowds
item.description: Applied physicist Iker Zuriguel studies the movement of particles and people to optimize their flow and improve public safety.
item.content:encoded: Applied physicist Iker Zuriguel studies the movement of particles and people to optimize their flow and improve public safety.
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel
